completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except for
the following:
CPA Rule 400.12212 Personnel records.
(2) The personnel record shall contain all of the following
information before employment may occur:
(d) Three references obtained from persons who are
unrelated to the staff person.
(f) If the employee has a criminal conviction, the chief
administrator or his or her designee shall complete
a written evaluation of the convictions that addresses
the nature of the conviction, the length of time the
conviction, and the relationship of the conviction to
regulated activity.
(g) A written statement from the employee regarding any
convictions.
(3) The personnel record shall both of the following:
(b) A copy of the job description for the staff member’s
current position.
Seven of fourteen personnel records reviewed were missing documentation per
the rule. Four of the fourteen personnel records were missing part (2, d) and only
had 2 references. One of the fourteen personnel records reviewed was missing
part (2, f) and (2, g) of the rule. Six of the fourteen personnel records reviewed
was missing part (3, b) of the rule.
CPA Rule 400. 12418 Development of service plans.

(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for each child
and parent or parents, as follows:
(b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial removal and at least
once every 90 calendar days thereafter.
Five of eight updated service plans reviewed were late. Service plans reviewed were
late ranging from 98 to 223 days late. (3 current open case records reviewed).
REPEAT VIOLATION RENEWAL DATED 6/25/21.
REPEAT VIOLATION INTERIM DATED 9/8/22.
CPA RULE 400.12605 Adoptive Family Evaluation
(1) An agency social service worker shall complete a written
adoptive evaluation within 90 days of the family signing
an adoption application to and prior to the approving a
family for adoption.
One of three adoptive family evaluation were not completed within 90 days
of the application. The report was four days late.
FOM 722-06B Family Team Meeting
FTM’s must occur within the required time frames
as outlined … Updated Case Plan (USP) – within 30
days prior to the service plan due date.
One of three open youth case records reviewed did not have documentation
that an FTM was held prior to the service plan due date.
REPEAT VIOLATION RENEWAL DATED 6/25/21.
REPEAT VIOLATION INTERIM DATED 9/8/22.
FOM 722 – 08D Treatment Plans – Agreements and signatures
Treatment Plans – Required Participation (PATP)
Once completed and approved, the caseworker must obtain signatures
from the following individuals, as applicable:
• Caseworker
• Supervisor
• Second line supervisor, when sibling in care are placed
apart.
• Parents who are a member of a participating household.
• Youth ages 14 and older.

• Foster parents, relative caregivers, and unrelated court-
ordered caregivers.
Parents/legal guardians, youths and caregivers must check yes or no for
the following when signing the treatment plan.
• I have participated in the development of the case service
plan and the parent agency service plan.
• I agree with the Case Service Plan and Parent Agency
Treatment Plan.
• I have been provided a copy of the Case Service Plan and
Parent Agency Agreement Plan to review, and I will have
the opportunity to express my disagreement with the Case
Service Plan Parent Agency Treatment Plan when the
information is presented to court.
Seven of eight youth case files reviewed were either missing required PATP
signatures, signatures not obtained within 30 days of the report due date of the report
or boxes not checked and missing dates of the signatures.

VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.

There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 3 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows. The
agency submitted three acceptable corrective actions plans (CAP) during this
licensing period, one CAP for the renewal inspection and two special
investigations. The compliance with each individual CAP is as follows:
One CAP was submitted as a result of the 9/8/2022 interim evaluation, CAP
received on 10/11/22. During this renewal review, there were repeat violations
and the agency did not implement their 2022 CAP effectively. See report for
repeat violations.
SI#2022C0420017 was initiated on 7/19/22 and CAP was accepted on 9/9/22. The
agency is working effectively on their corrective action plan.
SI# 2022C0201023 was initiated on 8/8/22 and CAP was received on 11/9/22. The
agency is working effectively on this CAP as there has been no repeat violation.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrator reported that the agency's previous years' staffing
turnover, left the agency significantly understaffed for the greater part of the
reporting period. All of the supervisors carried a caseload until March and April of
2023. This did have an impact on the agency's data analytics as all
managers/supervisors had increased duties to work toward ensuring that the
children remained in safe, stable placements while permanency was achieved.
Despite this continued changed, the agency has put a great emphasis on the in-
house training of staff and managers beyond CWTI and NSI to strengthen skill
sets, build competency and improve knowledge of program policies and
procedures. The current Corrective Action Plan has been used as a guide for
training and tracking. The managers continue to review areas of the plan in all
staff meetings and in individual unit meetings. The Division Director reviews the
Correction Action Plan with strategies of improvement with the managers as least
monthly.
Financial Overview
All audit of all financial accounts and budget for the fiscal year were reviewed. No
financial concerns were identified.
Staff and Youth Interviews
All staff interviewed were relatively new to the agency and was very enthusiastic
about being employed by the agency. They all expressed an interest in the
agency becoming more stable with the hiring of new supervisors and staff for each
program. However, they feel supported by their coworkers and the administrative

staff stating they have an open-door policy, and they can discuss any job-related
issues at any time.
There were no youth interviews.
Description of Agency Walk Through
The agency appears to have adequate space and equipment. Case files are
stored in locked rooms/cabinets which prevent unauthorized access.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
There were no safety alerts.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that Spectrum Child & Family Services will be issued a renewal of
their regular license.
